Turing Award 1983

Winners: Ken Thompson / Dennis Ritchie

Ritchie joined Thompson in developing a more flexible operating system for Bell Lab's obsolete Digital Equipment Corporation (DEC) PDP-7 minicomputer after the removal of the GE machines.

Thompson also invented a reimplementation of Unix's non-kernel parts based on BCPL and named the interpretive language B. Ritchie added types to B and eventually produced a compiler for C. Thompson and Ritchie greatly simplified Unix development by writing most of the system in C in 1973.

Dennis Ritchie and his partner in developing programming languages and operating systems received the Turing Award in 1983. The award that year was given to them thanks theory, and obviously also thanks to the implementation of the UNIX operating system. Another major invetion made by them was the creation and the developing of the programming language C.

Thanks to their revolutionary inventions and major developments in 1997, they were made a part of the Computer History Museum. Two years later they also received the National Medal of Technology, given by the President at the time Bill Clinton. According to what was said in the citation of the medal, "[They] led to enormous advances in computer hardware, software, and networking systems and stimulated growth of an entire industry, thereby enhancing American leadership in the Information Age".

In memory of A.M. Turing
